meta.content: Precipitation processes enable the fast preparation of a variety of inorganic materials, although typically with little control over their morphology. Now, their one-, two- or three-dimensional growth has been promoted simply by tuning the electrolytic dissociation of the reactants and the supersaturation of the solution.

volume
11

div.p: Precipitation processes enable the fast preparation of a variety of inorganic materials, although typically with little control over their morphology. Now, their one-, two- or three-dimensional growth has been promoted simply by tuning the electrolytic dissociation of the reactants and the supersaturation of the solution.
You have full access to this article via your institution.

Inorganic materials exhibit a variety of characteristics, such as their optical, electrical or catalytic properties, that make them very well suited to practical applications in areas ranging from electronics to energy storage and conversion. Control over their microstructure, morphology and size can help tailor the properties of functional materials to maximize device performances
1
,
2
. For example, Co
3
O
4
has been shown to exhibit morphology-dependent performances for alkali-ion batteries, with one-dimensional structures showing good electrochemical performances, owing to the short distances involved for ion diffusion and electron transport processes
3
. Co
3
O
4
octahedra and rods also show higher catalytic activity than cubes in fuel cells, metal–oxygen batteries and CO oxidation. This is because the active Co
3+
ions are present in different amounts on different facets, in the order of {111} > {110} > {100} — these facets are exposed for octahedra, rods and cubes, respectively
1
. Now, writing in
Nature Chemistry
, Wei-Hong Lai and co-workers
4
have coaxed inorganic materials into forming either one-, two- or three-dimensional structures, simply by tuning precursor solutions for precipitation processes.

Efforts to guide the growth of specific structures have traditionally focused on using organic surfactants or capping agents. Some capping agents can be selectively adsorbed on specific facets of inorganic nanocrystals, prohibiting crystal growth along these directions. Instead, growth occurs at the other facets, in turn enabling the final morphology to be tailored
5
,
6
. This approach has been used to engineer the surfaces and interfaces of inorganic materials. For instance, anatase TiO
2
plates, with their exposed {001} facets, show a more efficient photocatalytic degradation rate of methyl orange compared to belts and octahedra, with their exposed {010} and {101} facets, respectively, owing to the higher surface energy and abundance of active Ti
4+
of the {001} facets
6
. The downside of using surfactants or capping agents, however, is that they leave residues on the surface of the inorganic materials produced, which can in turn affect their chemistry
7
,
8
. For example, this can lower their performances for applications such as heterogeneous catalysis and ion intercalation (such as in secondary alkali-ion batteries)
9
,
10
,
11
. Furthermore, the additional costs and increased environmental footprint of the inevitable processing steps for removing residual organic capping agents impair the prospects of these synthetic strategies for commercial scale-up.

There have been prior instances of additive-free growth regulation. When nucleation occurs on a surface, nucleation and growth can both be guided by tailoring the substrate
12
,
13
. Win Noorduin and co-workers have recently combined control over local supersaturation with use of the polymorphic nature of calcium carbonate — and the resulting lattice mismatches between substrate and nuclei — to steer the nucleation and growth of BaCO
3
on different CaCO
3
substrates
13
; a variety of shapes were grown through sequential steps. In another study, Bingqian Cao and Weiping Cai reported
14
that ZnO structures grown on silicon substrates from chemical bath deposition can be tuned from rods to plates by increasing the concentration of the zinc nitrate used as a precursor. This increase causes a higher concentration of OH
–
in solution; those preferably adsorb on the <0001> planes of ZnO, hindering crystal growth along the rod axis and favouring instead a sideways growth along the
\(\left\langle {2\bar 1\bar 10} \right\rangle\)
directions to form ZnO plates.

In the present study, by choosing the most suitable parameters, the competitive kinetics of nucleation and particle growth can be precisely regulated through the release of reactant (
α
) so as to promote a crystal growth that is either isotropic or anisotropic (Fig.
1
). Poorly dissociating precursors (low
α
), such as NH
4
HF
2
and NH
4
OH, release reactant ions slowly, allowing them to deposit on preferred sites of the growing crystal to form anisotropic one- or two-dimensional morphologies. Tuning the concentration of the precursors to have either low or high supersaturation point (
S
) leads to one-dimensional (rod-like) or two-dimensional (sheet-like) materials, respectively. The lower supersaturation provides fewer nuclei, and also slows down their forming rate, thereby favouring a slow crystal growth into rods or wires. That is, heterogeneous nucleation (growth on existing nuclei) is favoured over homogenous nucleation (formation of new nuclei from the solution), and materials therefore tend to grow along a preferred direction according to a thermodynamic-controlled process. At higher supersaturation, homogeneous nucleation also occurs, with the formation of a larger number of nuclei that can divergently grow in kinetic-controlled processes
14
.

div.data-title: Schematic representation of the tuning of the reaction conditions to control the growth of inorganic materials.

figcaption.b: Fig. 1: Schematic representation of the tuning of the reaction conditions to control the growth of inorganic materials.

div.p:
In contrast, highly dissociating precursors (high
α
, with values around 1, such as NaF or NaOH) release ions quickly and in sufficient quantities to lead to fast precipitation processes that give three-dimensional morphologies. In this case, all of the ions released undergo nucleation, rather than growth on as-formed nuclei. The nuclei in turn agglomerate with each other into three-dimensional morphology through Ostwald ripening and particle attachment growth. Decreasing the supersaturation of the solution progressively increases the particles’ regularity: whereas at high
S
they tend to form spheres to irregular particles by lower degree of oriented or even random attachment of particles
15
. The higher
S
enables to grow all facets even including high-energy surfaces, which are usually excluded. The generalizability of this approach was illustrated by the preparation of hydroxides, carbonate and fluorides with controlled dimensionality.

The prospective applicability of this synthetic strategy to tune the morphology of inorganic electrode materials for energy conversion and storage is also explored. To illustrate the correlation between the dimensionality of inorganic electrode materials and their performances in those applications, Co(OH)
2
was shown to exhibit a better electrocatalytic performance for the aqueous oxygen evolution reaction when it is a rod-like material precipitated from the mixture of Co(NO
3
)
2
and NaF solution, rather than in two- or three-dimensional morphologies made from Co(NO
3
)
2
in a NH
4
OH solution and CoCO
3
in a NaOH solution, respectively. The electrocatalytic performances of BaF
2
for aqueous oxygen reduction reaction were also shown to be better in its two-dimensional morphology prepared from Ba(NO
3
)
2
and NH
4
HF
2
mixed solution, rather than one- and three-dimensional counterparts each synthesized from lower saturated solution with the same precursors and from the same concentration solution including NaF instead of NH
4
HF
2
.

The approach taken here shows that the simple tuning of the precursor solution enables precipitation processes to be steered towards the growth of materials in isotropic or anisotropic morphologies. This is truly important, in order to have better control over a material’s properties for specific applications — in particular, morphological adjustments appear to be crucial in the fields where the surfaces comprise the active species, such as electrocatalysis in non-aqueous systems (for example for metal–oxygen batteries), thermal catalysis for chemical transformations, as well as ion storage and transport (such as in electrode or solid-state electrolyte materials for alkali ion secondary batteries.
